thread.title: Hawaii News Now wins 3 Emmy Awards, including Lahaina wildfire coverage
thread.title_full: Hawaii News Now wins 3 Emmy Awards, including Lahaina wildfire coverage

author: @hawaiinewsnow
title: Hawaii News Now wins 3 Emmy Awards, including Lahaina wildfire coverage
text:
HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - Hawaii News Now took home 3 Emmy Awards Saturday night.
Two Emmys were awarded to the 4 and 6 p.m. newscasts covering the devastating Maui Wildfires . And the third was for news in the health category, in which HNN covered breaking the stigma around mental health .
“It is an honor to have the hard work and dedication of our news team acknowledged by NATAS and our media peers,” said Hawaii News Now News Director Scott Duff. “Being recognized for covering the impact of the Maui Wildfires and the continuing recovery highlights the commitment our newsroom has to serving the Maui community as well as the entire state of Hawaii.”
HNN was honored for:
“First at Four: Maui Wildfires Disaster,” Hawaii News Now KGMB/KHNL Anthony Ferreira, Bryce Hanamoto, Mark Carpenter, Ashley Nagaoka, Jennifer Robbins, Lynn Kawano, Jolanie Martinez, Jonathan Masaki, Mahealani Richardson, Peter Tang, Daniel Nunes and Tim Rubino “Hawaii News Now at 6: Maui Wildfires Devastation,” Hawaii News Now KGMB/KHNL Linda Kawachi, Mahealani Richardson, Allyson Blair, Chelsea Davis, Jonathan Suyat, Tim Rubino, Daniel Nunes “Ending the Silence: Breaking Mental Health Stigma,” Hawaii News Now KGMB/KHNL Megan Ramones
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Hawaii News Now (@hawaiinewsnow)
Hawaii News Now’s General Manager Katie Pickman said the awards are significant to the entire team.
“It’s an honor to work beside these dedicated and talented individuals,” she said. “This recognition for the work by Hawaii News Now underscores the phenomenal efforts by our news team to highlight the critical issues and challenges faced by our community every day.”
The NATAS San Francisco/Northern California chapter is comprised of broadcast and cable television stations in Northern California, Hawaii, Guam and Reno, Nevada.
